multiple-choice.question: What type of waves does light energy travel in?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes them rotate in the same direction.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes them rotate, as their positive and negative regions are pushed and pulled in different directions.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on them.

options.label: A
options.text: They interact weakly, resulting in minimal heating.

options.label: B
options.text: They interact strongly, making the molecules jostle against each other and creating frictional heat.

options.label: C
options.text: They have no interaction, resulting in no heating.

options.label: D
options.text: They interact variably, depending on the food composition.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when microwaves encounter polar molecules in the food, like water molecules?

options.label: A
options.text: They make them vibrate at low frequencies.

options.label: B
options.text: They make them vibrate at high frequencies.

options.label: C
options.text: They have no effect on them.

options.label: D
options.text: They make them move in the same direction.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary mechanism of heating food in a microwave oven?

options.label: B
options.text: Frictional heat generated by molecular vibration

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you microwave a marshmallow?

options.label: C
options.text: It heats the moisture trapped within its gelatin-sugar matrix, making the hot air expand and the marshmallow puff.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on it.

options.label: A
options.text: Ionizing radiation that can alter chemical bonds

options.label: B
options.text: Non-ionizing radiation that can only generate heat through molecular vibration

options.label: C
options.text: High frequency radiation that can cause DNA damage

options.label: D
options.text: Low frequency radiation that has no effect on molecules

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They have no effect on the food.

options.label: A
options.text: To prevent overheating of the oven.

options.label: C
options.text: To limit exposure to microwave radiation as a precautionary measure.

title: How to know if you're being selfish (and whether or not that's bad) - Mark Hopwood

multiple-choice.question: According to the idea of psychological egoism, what is the primary motivator of human actions?

options.label: A
options.text: A desire for social recognition and status

options.label: B
options.text: The pursuit of one's own self-interest

options.label: C
options.text: A need for emotional connection and relationships

options.label: D
options.text: A sense of moral duty to others

multiple-choice.question: Which philosopher stated that "of all voluntary acts, the object is to every man his own good", suggesting that human beings are inherently selfish?
According to Aristotle, what is necessary for humans to flourish and reach their full potential?

options.label: A
options.text: The pursuit of self-interest and personal gain

options.label: B
options.text: The cultivation of virtues such as generosity and justice, and seeking the good of others as well as oneself

options.label: C
options.text: The pursuit of social status and recognition

options.label: D
options.text: The development of emotional connections and relationships alone

multiple-choice.question: Which philosophers believed that emotions like pity and sympathy play a crucial role in allowing us to consider the needs and interests of others?
According to Iris Murdoch, what is a key characteristic of human selfishness and the way it distorts our perception of reality?

options.label: A
options.text: A tendency to prioritize one's own needs over others

options.label: B
options.text: A lack of self-awareness and introspection

options.label: C
options.text: A tendency to see the world in a way that casts oneself as a star and everyone else as secondary characters

options.label: D
options.text: A need for self-preservation and personal security alone

multiple-choice.question: Which philosopher believed that a certain kind of love, characterized by a deep recognition of the reality of others, is the only true solution to human selfishness?
According to Iris Murdoch, what is the key to overcoming human selfishness and developing a more realistic and loving perception of others?

options.label: A
options.text: The cultivation of virtues such as generosity and justice alone

options.label: B
options.text: The practice of attention, which helps direct one's attention beyond the self and cultivate a deeper awareness of reality

options.label: C
options.text: The pursuit of self-interest and personal gain

options.label: D
options.text: The development of emotional connections and relationships alone

multiple-choice.question: Which philosopher argued that humans are fundamentally social beings who can only flourish and reach their full potential when we seek the good of others as well as ourselves?
According to Iris Murdoch, what is the definition of love in the context of overcoming selfishness and developing a more realistic perception of others?

options.label: A
options.text: The pursuit of self-interest and personal gain

options.label: B
options.text: The cultivation of virtues such as generosity and justice alone

options.label: C
options.text: The reduction of others to caricatures and stereotypes

options.label: D
options.text: The extremely difficult realization that something other than oneself is real

options.label: C
